so time for a bit of anatomy images are
processed on the back of your eye on a
layer of light-sensitive cells known as
rods and cones there are two different
types there are rods that are
responsible for seeing when there's low
light levels and cones that are
responsible for seeing when it's
daylight and when you're looking at
various colors as well there are 3
different types of cone cells that allow
you to perceive light wavelengths as
color there's the ones that are
responsible for seeing red light ones
for blue light and ones for green light
and they can also team up so you can see
all the different colors of the rainbow
so for example you can get red and blue
teaming together so you can see purple
now color blindness happens when one or
more of those types of cone cells are
missing or are faulty it's usually
hereditary so it's normally in your
genes it's passed down through your
family from your parents and but it can
be caused by illness or aging or
exposure to some types of chemicals as
well red-green color blindness is the
most common and it's more likely to
affect men than it is women and the
reason why is really interesting it's
down to our chromosomes they contain our
genes which are basically the
instruction manual for how to make
proteins which build up into into cells
and tissues and up into organs now we
all have 23 pairs of chromosomes and
this color blindness red green is all
down to the 23rd pair the final pair
which are known as the sex chromosomes
now now females have two X chromosomes
whereas men males have One X of one
pibbly or Y chromosome and the gene
that's responsible for the red-green
color blindness now women have to have
two of those I have to have one on each
of the X square
for it to be ineffective you to have

blind than women interestingly blue

equally and that's because the gene for
